claim: If video recordings of lectures are provided, nothing in particular happens to class attendance.

supporting.text: Studies have shown that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact attendance, as students still value in-person interaction and real-time Q&A.

attacks.text: Studies have shown that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact attendance, as students still value in-person interaction and real-time Q&A.
Other studies indicate that lecture recordings lead to decreased attendance because students prefer the flexibility of watching lectures at their own pace.
The availability of recordings may create a false sense of security, leading students to skip classes and fall behind in coursework.
Students who skip live lectures often miss out on spontaneous discussions and networking opportunities, which are not captured in recordings.
Recordings can enhance learning for students who attend lectures by allowing them to review complex material, thus supporting attendance.
The convenience of recordings may disproportionately benefit students with disabilities or caregiving responsibilities, who might otherwise struggle to attend.

supporting.text: Many students attend lectures for reasons beyond content delivery, such as peer interaction, structured learning environments, or instructor expectations, which recordings do not replace.

attacks.text: Many students attend lectures for reasons beyond content delivery, such as peer interaction, structured learning environments, or instructor expectations, which recordings do not replace.
Some students may find peer interaction and structured environments less critical if they can access lecture content flexibly through recordings.
Instructor expectations can often be met through alternative means, such as online forums or virtual office hours, reducing the need for physical attendance.
Flexible access to recordings may lead to isolation, reducing the quality of peer interaction and collaborative learning opportunities.
Virtual interactions often lack the spontaneity and depth of in-person discussions, making them less effective for learning.
Students can supplement virtual interactions with in-person study groups, maintaining peer interaction benefits while enjoying the flexibility of recordings.
Structured online discussions and scheduled virtual meetings can replicate much of the spontaneity and depth of in-person interactions.

supporting.text: In cases where attendance is mandatory or graded, the availability of recordings has little to no effect on student presence in class.

attacks.text: In cases where attendance is mandatory or graded, the availability of recordings has little to no effect on student presence in class.
Even with mandatory attendance, students may skip class and rely on recordings if enforcement is lax or penalties are minimal.
Recordings can reduce the perceived value of in-person attendance, leading to lower engagement even if attendance is technically required.
Studies show that strict enforcement of attendance policies significantly mitigates the negative impact of lecture recordings on attendance.
Institutions with clear penalties for non-attendance see higher compliance regardless of recording availability.
Interactive or discussion-based classes maintain high attendance rates despite recordings, as their value isn't fully captured in video.

supporting.text: Some research indicates that lecture recordings can actually decrease attendance, as students may prioritize convenience over in-person participation.

attacks.text: Some research indicates that lecture recordings can actually decrease attendance, as students may prioritize convenience over in-person participation.
Other studies show no significant change in attendance when lecture recordings are provided, suggesting student behavior varies by context.
Lecture recordings can enhance learning for those who attend in person by allowing them to review material, which may indirectly support attendance.
The studies showing no change in attendance often lack control for external factors like course difficulty or instructor quality.
Students who review recordings may still miss key interactive elements of in-person lectures, undermining the convenience argument.

supporting.text: Students with access to recordings may skip lectures more frequently, assuming they can catch up later, leading to lower overall attendance rates.

attacks.text: Students with access to recordings may skip lectures more frequently, assuming they can catch up later, leading to lower overall attendance rates.
Many students still prefer attending lectures in person for real-time interaction and immediate clarification of doubts.
Recordings can actually enhance attendance by allowing students to review difficult concepts, making them more confident and engaged in subsequent lectures.
Studies show that students who attend lectures in person perform better on assessments, which incentivizes attendance despite the availability of recordings.
The flexibility of recordings can reduce stress, leading to more consistent attendance when students feel less pressured.
In-person attendance fosters a sense of community and accountability, which recordings cannot replicate.

supporting.text: The flexibility of recordings can encourage procrastination, where students delay watching lectures and eventually disengage from attending live sessions altogether.

attacks.text: The flexibility of recordings can encourage procrastination, where students delay watching lectures and eventually disengage from attending live sessions altogether.
Many students still prefer live sessions for real-time interaction and immediate clarification of doubts, maintaining attendance levels.
Procrastination is a personal habit issue, not directly caused by the availability of lecture recordings.
Studies show that students who attend live sessions perform better in assessments, incentivizing attendance despite recording availability.
The presence of recordings can reduce anxiety about missing lectures, making students more likely to attend when they can.
Educational institutions often design courses to require live participation, ensuring attendance remains stable.
Time management training can mitigate procrastination, addressing the issue without removing recordings.
